utterance: Gort's truth-ain't there any hankerchers hanging out of back pockets now?
speaker: John Dax's father

utterance: Oh, my gracious! look here, Ellen-look here, Mary
speaker: Mrs. Morison

utterance:
here's your father come home again in such a state!
Here's Oh no! it isn't Morison, it's another one. Come and help me get him off the premises.
speaker: Mrs. Morison

utterance: Mary
speaker: Mrs. Morison

utterance: It's not any one intoxicated.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: It's a poor fellow in a fit.
speaker: Mary Morison

utterance: What's the matter?
speaker: Mr. Morison

utterance: whateverth ith the matter?
speaker: Mr. Morison

utterance: It's a poor lad taken ill; we've brought him in-doors for a moment.
speaker: Mrs. Morison

utterance: I wouldn't have put him on the top of the Noah's arks,
speaker: Mr. Morison

utterance: he's damaging the property.
speaker: Mr. Morison

utterance: He's coming round.
speaker: Mary Morison

utterance: Where's this-wot's this?
speaker: John Dax

utterance: This is Morison's Repository, Gibbon Street, young man.
speaker: Mr. Morison

utterance: Oh! is it?
speaker: John Dax

utterance: And I hope you haven't been drinking to account for this state?
speaker: Mr. Morison

utterance: No,
speaker: John Dax

utterance: nor eatin' either-wus luck!
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Starving!
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: oh, see! he looks like it, poor fellow!
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: When did you have any thing to eat last?
speaker: Mary Morison

utterance: Or drink last?
speaker: Mr. Morison

utterance: Can't remember; yesterday, I think.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Not to-day-at all?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Not to-day-blest if I have.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: See to him, let us do something,
speaker: Mary Morison

utterance: free and gratis,
speaker: John Dax

utterance: No, thankee-for nuffink, please, if you'll let me jest this time!
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Is any thing the matter, John ?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Yes-there is a little the matter,
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Are you ill?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: No, I ain't ill,
speaker: John Dax

utterance: but the old un is.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Your father?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Yes; he's going off the hooks at last.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Tell her.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Tell whom?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Miss Mary: she was asking after the guvnor last week.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: She is well, I suppose?
speaker: John Dax

utterance: She is quite well, thank you,
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: She was looking very pale last week, I fancied,
speaker: John Dax

utterance: You have let her talk too much; you have been inconsiderate.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: I have been as careful as I could, but your sister had a good deal to tell me.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Of our long quarrel? Ah, it was hardly necessary that you should know it.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: I think it was.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: And yet she was anxious about you of late days. There was a reason for it, I suppose?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance:
Yes, Miss Ellen, there was a reason.
The money up stairs-you remember.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: What of that?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: She--she never-
speaker: John Dax

utterance: It was lent to her to buy Alec's discharge, to pay his passage back to England, to help him in any way upon his journey.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Lent by you-for her sake!
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: What use was the money to me, when she was fretting for the soldier away in India?
speaker: John Dax

utterance: You can never be repaid.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: I don't care to be, though I am not so sure of it, for all that.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: John, I did not think you could be so kind and generous as this. Why did you not tell me before?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: It was a little surprise of mine.
speaker: John Dax

utterance:
A surprise indeed. And you have known Mary's love story all the while, and sympathized with her and helped her, and forgotten your own poor foolish dreams!
And yet-
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: I have not known every thing very clearly till to-day, there was a little mystery-not much-and Miss Mary has set that right at last. As for Alec-
speaker: John Dax

utterance: His coming back will end the long quarrel, won't it?
speaker: John Dax

utterance: She was never to speak to me till he came back again, and he is on his way. Yes,
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: for that one reason I shall be glad to see him.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: I thought you would. You don't bear malice now?
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Malice! Do you think I-
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Has Mary told you the story of our quarrel?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Most of it. She said you would tell the rest.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: How I loved Alec Williamson first, and how she came between us?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Yes, and how you continued to separate them until-
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Until, in the bitterness of his disappointment, he enlisted for a soldier, poor martyr, Well, well, John, let her version of the story stand; it is not deserving of further explanation, and I am too proud to offer it.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: There is one favor I want to ask of you before I go away this morning.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: You can not ask a favor of us that will be refused, if it lie in our power to grant it.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: It is in your power only.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: What is it?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: When I first came back I spoke of my foolish love for the poor girl up stairs.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: It died out, of course-that is, any hope I had died off clean when I heard about the soldier, and when we were arranging our plans to buy him off, and so on.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: I am glad yon did not brood upon it at all.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance:
And my only trouble now is that Mary
-Miss Mary, as I ought to call her still,
speaker: John Dax

utterance: should ever hear of my silly fancy for her. I don't want any body to know this. I wish I'd never told you a word about it now.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: It might do her good to hear the story some day.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: No, it wouldn't, and it makes me look soft and stupid. I'm both; I know that; you know it too, and are smiling at me, though you try hard to look serious; but I couldn't help liking her a great deal once. But don't tell her so-ever-will you?
speaker: John Dax

utterance: I will not.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: That's right. I can go back to my work now jolly. It seems all squaring round so well. Miss Mary getting stronger, forgetting and forgiving every thing you have done to her, and her young man coming back from India to make her heart light for ever and ever. Why, this is capital.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: And all this your doing, it is from your sacrifice that the happiness will spring. What have we done to deserve it?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: You were kind to me in the old days, I can't forget it.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: And, John, we will never forget you.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Thankee, thankee.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Our only friend, our best friend, God bless you!
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Ah! Ellen, is that you? There's nothing the matter, I hope?
speaker: John Dax

utterance: There is nothing wrong, but there is something the matter, John, can't you guess what it is ?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Yes, I think I can.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: He has come back?
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: He is at the repository?
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Was Mary very pleased to see him?
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Very pleased. I did not hear what she said. I came into the street and left them together. I could not stop.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Not to speak a word to Mary, after all these awful years!
speaker: John Dax

utterance: I shall see her presently, I did not wish to mar the first moments of their meeting by my interference. They will not miss me, and I thought I would come and meet you.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: The happiness has come at last. I am glad.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Very glad?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Yes. It settles the matter, you see.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: I think I see more than this.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: What's that?
speaker: John Dax

utterance: That you are the most unselfish man whom I have ever met.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Oh, nonsense!
speaker: John Dax

utterance: The one unselfish man, I might have said, and yet there was a time when Mary and I looked down upon you, pitied you, and patronized you.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: And if it had not been for your pity and your patronage-
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Pray don't be grateful to us any more, The times are changed, and we have changed places with them. Here is home.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: It will be like home at last, I hope.
speaker: John Dax

utterance:
Amen.
I hope so.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Mary.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: At last.
speaker: Mary Morison

utterance: This is the best friend we have ever had in our lives. Your best friend too, Alec, for it was his sovereigns that saved you.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Sir, I thank ye, I am proud to make yeer acquaintance; a freend of my Mary's is a freend of mine for life, Sir-for life.
speaker: Alec Williamson

utterance: You are very good.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: You will be glad to hear, John, that Alec has seen some of his relations, and he is likely to obtain a situation almost at once.
speaker: Mary Morison

utterance: Yes, I am glad of that.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Then we shall begin saving for you,
speaker: Mary Morison

utterance: If ever so little.
speaker: Alec Williamson

utterance: To pay off the debt we owe you.
speaker: Mary Morison

utterance: You need not trouble about that-for a year or two.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Sit ye down, mon, sit ye down; ye hae been a guid freend to us.
speaker: Alec Williamson

utterance: I should think soldiering not a bad idea for a man, take it all together.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Ay, for a mon who gaes awa' to serve his countrie honestly, for there's glory in it. But it's vera ill soldierin' with a trooble or a wrang at the heart.
speaker: Alec Williamson

utterance: Ay, but for a fellow with no ties, no wrongs, no troubles, nothing to keep him at a trade, and only an empty top room that he can call his home, I should say the army was the thing, now.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Why, you are not thinking of the army, John?
speaker: Mary Morison

utterance: Why should I?
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Wait an instant, John.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Have you bidden them good-by?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: No, no; they were busy-
speaker: John Dax

utterance: Busy?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: That is, they were very happy sweethearting, and it was a pity to disturb them.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: But you are going away for a long while?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: How do you know?
speaker: John Dax

utterance: I read it in your face to-night. Is it not true?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Well, yes; for-
speaker: John Dax

utterance: For what?
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: For it's no use coming to trouble either of you again. I-I sha'n't want to come now.
speaker: John Dax

utterance: They will be glad to see you at the wedding.
speaker: Ellen Morison

utterance: Oh no, no, thank you!
speaker: John Dax

utterance: You are her friend and mine, and we are short of friends. Mary will go soon to her new home, and I shall be very lonely here, if even you will not look in to say good-evening sometimes.
speaker: Ellen Morison
